A delegation of Africa CDC, led by Dr. Tajudeen Raji, paid a courtesy call to Hon. Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah, DPM and Minister of International Relations and Cooperation of Namibia, to brief her on their week-long visit in support of Namibia’s efforts to contain #COVID19 Pandemic. The Delegation informed of the continental and international efforts aimed at building Africa’s capacity to fight and mitigate the effects of the pandemic, and affirmed the Africa CDC’s solidarity to continue supporting the Government and People of the Namibia in this regard.  #NewPublicHealthOrder #AfricaResponds  Ministry of International Relations and Cooperation Namibia  -*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-  Une délégation de Africa CDC, conduite par le Dr Tajudeen Raji, a rendu une visite de courtoisie à l'honorable Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah, Vice Premier Ministre et Ministre des relations internationales et de la coopération de la Namibie, pour l'informer de leur visite d'une semaine en soutien aux efforts de la Namibie pour contenir la pandémie #COVID19. La délégation a discuté des efforts continentaux et internationaux visant à renforcer la capacité de l'Afrique à combattre et à atténuer les effets de la pandémie. Elle a également affirmé la solidarité de Africa CDC à soutenir le gouvernement et le peuple de la Namibie à cet égard.  #NewPublicHealthOrder #AfricaResponds  Ministry of International Relations and Cooperation Namibia

Le Chef de Division Prévention et Contrôle des Maladies de Africa CDC, Dr Abdulaziz Mohammed, a présidé aujourd'hui une réunion de consultation avec le personnel du Ministère de la Santé Publique du Cameroun pour accélérer l'implémentation de l'initiative "Sauver des vies & des moyens de subsistance".  Lors de la consultation, le Cameroun a fait une évaluation des besoins & 3 domaines ont été identifiés pour un soutient immmédiat à savoir: #Engagement Communautaire pr générer la demande de vaccins, #Augmenter les centres de vaccination, #Ressources humaines & logistique ds le pays. #AfricaResponds #COVID19

Africa CDC, #PandemicAction African Union, 3M and over 50 global, regional, and local partner organizations announced the launch of #WorldMaskWeek 2021 (July 12-18) — a global campaign underlining a universal truth: masking in public 😷, in combination with handwashing 👏 and physical distancing, is still one of the best ways we can protect ourselves and others against #COVID19, especially our most vulnerable community members as countries race to vaccinate their populations.   More information 👇 https://bit.ly/3AY86zM

As the pandemic continues to spread, we must fight against pandemic fatigue and continue masking to protect our friends, our families, our communities, and the world.  Join us for #WorldMaskWeek, wear your mask and tag someone to say #ThanksforMasking. #COVID19 #AfricaResponds

The Partnerships for African Vaccine Manufacturing (PAVM) was launched by H.E Felix Tshisekedi, Chair of the African Union and President of the Democratic Republic of Congo, during a virtual summit hosted by the African Union Commission (AUC) and the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) on 12-13th April 2021 under the theme “Expanding Africa’s Vaccine Manufacturing for Health Security: Building back better, bolder and bigger.” Since the Summit, several countries have made remarkable progress. Read more 👇

TIME FOR ACTION: With over 40 AU member states participating in a continental dialogue on emergency expedited regulatory authorization for COVID-19 vaccines, stakes are high regarding how these states will collaborate to fast track access to COVID-19 vaccines for the continent. #CovidVaccine4Africa

Africa countries must jointly address barriers that affect COVID-19 vaccine procurement, importation, transportation and distribution, while maintaining international standards of safety, efficacy, and quality. #CovidVaccine4Africa

Addressing regulatory challenges is one of the keys to ensure the African continent is not handicapped in its efforts to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic as quickly as possible. #CovidVaccine4Africa

When countries work together on regulatory approvals, especially in regional economic communities (RECs), significant progress can be made to reduce the time required for regulatory approvals of medicines crucial for addressing public health priorities. #CovidVaccine4Africa

Every AU member state must fast track its readiness for COVID-19 vaccines by ensuring an efficient regulatory environment, streamlined decision-making processes, and a delivery programme that is fit for purpose. #CovidVaccine4Africa Africa CDC  AUDA NEPAD African Union  @AfricasVaccine @WHOAFRO @PATHadvocacy @PATHtweets

NRAs in Africa must work together to remove barriers to regulation & approval of COVID-19 💉 across Africa, through fast-tracking country authorization of safe & effective COVID-19 💉.  #CovidVaccine4Africa

Safety First: While equitable access remains key, any COVID-19 vaccine that is approved by African NRAs must meet the highest standards of international quality, safety & efficacy. #CovidVaccine4Africa

CALL FOR PROPOSALS FOR COVID-19 RISK COMMUNICATION AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT (RCCE) IN AFRICA The Africa CDC, African Union, and the Mastercard Foundation invite proposals from implementing partners to provide implementation services to support Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) in relation to COVID-19 vaccination rollout in African Union Member States.  The overall objective of this call for proposal is to support African Union Member States in designing, implementing, monitoring and evaluating the RCCE activities necessary for scaling up COVID-19 vaccination to at least 60 per cent coverage of their populations with safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines by 2022. More at https://africacdc.org/download/covid-19-risk-communication-and-community-engagement-rcce-in-africa/ #AfricaResponds #COVID19 #NewPublicHealthOrder

On 29 June 2021, Africa CDC handed over a consignment worth about 80,000 USD of COVID-19 supplies to the Government of the Republic of Zambia represented by Dr Kennedy Malama, Permanent Secretary Technical services Ministry of Health. The hand over which took place at the Kenneth Kaunda International airport had in attendance Dr Lul Riek, the Regional Coordinator of the Southern Africa Regional Collaborating Centre (RCC), the Africa CDC HQ delegation led by Dr Merawi Aragaw, Ministry of health officials and staff of the Southern RCC.   The Ministry of Health expressed gratitude to Africa CDC for the timely donation as Zambia grapples a deadly third wave of the COVID-19 Pandemic. The Africa CDC delegation will spend the next days consulting with various response pillars on areas of further support to Zambia. #AfricaResponds #COVID19 #NewPublicHealthOrder #ZNPHI #MoHZambia

The African Union Commission and the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) noted with concern recent communications regarding the applicability of the EU Digital COVID Certificate “Green Pass” to different COVID-19 vaccines. The availability of such a Certificate, with its potential to significantly facilitate free safe movement across all EU Member States and certain associated countries, is a significant step forward. However, the current applicability guidelines put at risk the equitable treatment of persons having received their vaccines in countries profiting from the EU-supported COVAX Facility, including the majority of the African Union (AU) Member States. More at 🔗 https://africacdc.org/download/statement-on-covishield-and-the-european-union-eu-digital-covid-certificate-green-pass/ #COVID19 #AfricaResponds #COVIDCertificate #Digital

Validation workshop in Dakar, Senegal (for Western Africa Member States). 21-23 June, 2021. The aim of this workshop is to validate two draft  policy and standard documents titled 'Africa Union Health Information Exchange Policy and Standards for Health Information Systems' and the 'African Union Policy Reccomandations on digital solutions to trace, diagnose and share information about pandemics in Africa' which will facilitate the standardization and interoperability of the multiple information systems. This inturn will strengthen data acquisition, warehousing and use. #AfricaResponds #DigitalSolutions #Pandemics

FORMATION SUR LE SYSTÈME DE BASE DE GESTION DE LA QUALITÉ DES LABORATOIRES UTILISANT L’APPROCHE ONE HEALTH PENDANT LA PANDÉMIE DE COVID-19, 21-25 JUIN 2021, LUSAKA, ZAMBIE  Atelier de formation sur le système de gestion de la qualité des laboratoires (LQMS) avec un objectif général d’assurer l’amélioration continue des processus de diagnostic, d’investigation et d’examen de la qualité des laboratoires conformément à l’approche « Une seule santé » pendant la pandémie de COVID-19 Au moins trente-cinq (35) experts de laboratoire (professionnels de la santé animale et humaine) de la Zambie auront des compétences sur le LQMS. #AfricaResponds #COVID19

TRAINING ON BASIC LABORATORY QUALITY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM USING THE ONE HEALTH APPROACH DURING COVID-19 PANDEMIC, 21-25 JUNE 2021, LUSAKA, ZAMBIA  Training workshop on laboratory quality management system (LQMS) with a broad objective of ensuring continuous improvement of the laboratory quality diagnosis, investigation and examination processes in line with the One Health approach during #COVID19 pandemic At least thirty five (35) laboratory experts (animal and human health professionals) from Zambia will have skills on LQMS. #AfricaResponds

Africa CDC launches Fellowship of Kofi Annan Global Health Leadership Programme  On 12 April 2021, the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and the Kofi Annan Foundation launched the Fellowship of Kofi Annan Global Health Leadership Programme which aims to support senior aspirational African public health leaders acquire advanced skills for transformational public health leadership in Africa. The programme is the first initiative under the Kofi Annan Global Health Leadership Program (KA-GHLP) that was launched on 25 May 2020 by the African Union Commission (AUC) and Africa CDC.  https://africacdc.org/news-item/africa-cdc-launches-fellowship-of-kofi-annan-global-health-leadership-programme/  #KofiAnnanFoundation #GlobalHealthLeadership #GlobalHealthProgramme #AfricaResponds  #NewPublicHealthOrder

African Union and the Africa CDC’s Africa Regulatory Taskforce has endorsed the Emergency Used Authorization for Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine.  The Africa Regulatory Taskforce is a joint effort established by the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), the African Union Development Agency (AUDA NEPAD) coordinated African Medicines Regulatory Harmonization (AMRH) Initiative, and the World Health Organization (WHO)'s African Vaccine Regulatory Forum (AVAREF) to enable and provide support for an effective regulatory framework for COVID-19 Vaccines in Africa.  More 👇 https://africacdc.org/download/african-union-and-the-africa-centers-for-disease-control-and-preventions-africa-regulatory-taskforce-has-endorsed-the-emergency-used-authorization-for-janssen-covid-19-vaccine-2/  #AfricaResponds #VaccinesForAfrica #FactsNotFear

African Union, Africa CDC & MasterCard Foundation Launch Saving Lives and Livelihood initiative | June 8, 2021  Powered by Restream https://restream.io/  Press Briefing: A Partnership for COVID-19 Vaccination in Africa  Contact us @AfricaCDC (Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Instagram) Email: africacdc@africa-union.org Telephone: +251 11 551 77 00

The Mastercard Foundation has announced that it will deploy $1.3 billion over the next three years in partnership with the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) to save the lives and livelihoods of millions of people in Africa and hasten the economic recovery of the continent.  “Ensuring equitable access and delivery of vaccines across Africa is urgent. This initiative is about valuing all lives and accelerating the economic recovery of the continent,” said Reeta Roy, President and CEO of the Mastercard Foundation. “In the process, this initiative will catalyze work opportunities in the health sector and beyond as part of our Young Africa Works strategy,” she added.  “Ensuring inclusivity in vaccine access, and building Africa’s capacity to manufacture its own vaccines, is not just good for the continent, it’s the only sustainable path out of the pandemic and into a health-secure future,” said Dr. John Nkengasong, Director of the Africa CDC. “This partnership with the Mastercard Foundation is a bold step towards establishing a New Public Health Order for Africa, and we welcome other actors to join this historic journey.”  More at https://africacdc.org/news-item/mastercard-foundation-to-deploy-1-3-billion-in-partnership-with-africa-cdc-to-save-lives-and-livelihoods/ #COVID19 #AfricaResponds #NewPublicHealthOrder #FactsNotFear #VaccineForAfrica #SavingLives #SavingLivelihoods #SavingEconomies

The COVID-19 vaccine Ad26.COV2.S, developed by Janssen (Johnson & Johnson), is a human adenovirus based vaccine which is administered as a single dose regimen to prevent COVID-19, with a demonstrated efficacy of 66% overall and 57% in a context with predominance of the 501Y.V2 SARS-COV-2 variant.  On 13th April 2021, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US CDC) and Food and Drug Administration (FDA), out of an abundance of caution, have recommended a pause in the use of Janssen’s COVID-19 vaccine due to reports of an extremely rare disorder involving blood clots in combination with low platelets in individuals who have received the COVID-19 vaccine.

The Role of Regional Public Health Institutions in Improving Disease Surveillance and Response in Eastern and Southern Africa.  Register at https://bit.ly/3qIEQqE and join our keynote speakers and experts to discuss the findings of a regional study and action plan for strengthening disease surveillance, emergency-response capabilities, & lab networks in Africa through #RISLNET.  Date:  March 18th, 2021  Time: 15.00—16.30 hrs. (EAT/GMT+3) Link: https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZAsc-2vqjkiHND3qR8kVRYtZah6KE4ODJ1B  Key Speakers: - Dr. Muhammad Pate, Global Director for Health, Nutrition and Population, World Bank - Dr. John Nkengasong, Director, Africa CDC - Ms. Yujin Jeong, Director, Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency - Dr. Deborah Wetzel, Director, Regional Integration, World Bank.  Presenter: - Dr. Pascale Ondoa, ASLM Director of Science and New Initiatives.  Panelists: - Dr. Achamyelesh Kifle Debela, EA-RCC Director - Dr. Lul Pout Riek, SA-RCC Director - Dr. Ebba Abate, EPHI Director - Dr. Victor Mukonka, ZNPHI Director - Dr. Ambrose Otau Talisuna, WHO Team Lead for Emergency Preparedness - Ms. Myranda Lutempo, Policy Officer at the African Union Regional Office, SADC Representative.  Moderator: - Dr. Abdulaziz Mohammed, Africa CDC Head of Division, Disease Control and Prevention.  Chair: - Dr. Patricia Geli, Senior Economist, Health, Nutrition, and Population, World Bank.

We finished training the last group of 25 #HCW today. A total of 75 HCW were trained over the week. The training was on #COVID19 Quality sample collection and #Biosafety precautions when handling and processing samples in response to the #COVID19 pandemic.   With over  80 HCW now trained on how to safely collect and perform the rapid antigen test in the district, we hope to see a rapid increase in testing, tracing and treatment which is part of the #PACT initiative led by Africa CDC.   Gaps now remaining is to supply the district with more rapid antigen kits and to do the same trainings in other districts in midlands and other provinces. #PACT #AfricaResponds #TestTraceTreat

AFRICA CDC ET EDCTP S'ASSOCIENT POUR FORMER DES ÉPIDÉMIOLOGISTES ET DES BIOSTATISTICIENS HAUTEMENT QUALIFIÉS EN AFRIQUE  Un nouveau programme de formation financé par le Partenariat des pays Européens et en Développement sur les Essais Cliniques (EDCTP) et les Centres Africains pour la Prévention et le Contrôle des Maladies (Africa CDC) est destiné à soutenir la formation de 150 épidémiologistes et biostatisticiens hautement qualifiés en Afrique subsaharienne sur une période de trois ans.  La formation devrait commencer en octobre 2021 et se terminer en 2024. Elle sera dirigée par dix consortiums composés d'institutions d'Afrique et d'Europe. Lorsqu'il sera achevé, le programme renforcera la capacité des Instituts Nationaux de Santé Publique, des Ministères de la Santé et d'autres institutions sanitaires en Afrique à mener collectivement des recherches en santé publique et à répondre efficacement aux situations d'urgence sanitaire sur le continent.  "Pour renforcer les systèmes de santé en Afrique, nous devons prêter attention à notre personnel de santé et trouver des moyens de renforcer leurs capacités. Une main-d'œuvre hautement qualifiée capable de mettre en œuvre une surveillance multi-maladie et de répondre efficacement aux épidémies est nécessaire pour notre sécurité sanitaire collective sur le continent, et c'est ce dont il s'agit dans ce programme", a déclaré le Dr John Nkengasong, Directeur, Africa CDC.  Plus d'informations sur https://africacdc.org/news-item/africa-cdc-and-edctp-partner-to-train-highly-skilled-epidemiologists-and-biostatisticians-in-africa/

AFRICA CDC AND EDCTP PARTNER TO TRAIN HIGHLY SKILLED EPIDEMIOLOGISTS AND BIOSTATISTICIANS IN AFRICA  A new training programme funded by the European and Developing Countries Clinical Trials Partnership (EDCTP) and the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is set to support the training of 150 highly skilled epidemiologists and biostatisticians in sub-Saharan Africa over a period of three years.  The training is expected to start by October 2021 and end by 2024 and will be led by ten consortiums comprised of institutions from Africa and Europe. When completed, the programme will boost the capacity of National Public Health Institutes, Ministries of Health and other health institutions in Africa to collectively conduct public health research and effectively respond to disease emergencies across the continent.  “To strengthen healthcare systems in Africa, we must pay attention to our healthcare workforce and find ways to strengthen their capacity. A highly skilled workforce that can implement multi-disease surveillance and effectively respond to disease outbreaks is necessary for our collective health security in the continent, and this is what this programme is about,” said Dr John Nkengasong, Director of Africa CDC.  More at https://africacdc.org/news-item/africa-cdc-and-edctp-partner-to-train-highly-skilled-epidemiologists-and-biostatisticians-in-africa/

The Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation (STBF) has awarded a grant of US$11.5 million to the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) to strengthen sexual and reproductive health services in Africa.  During public health emergencies, African countries often face the dilemma of responding to outbreaks to save lives while at the same time struggling to allocate resources to other healthcare services. Since the onset of the COVID-19, African Union Member States have channeled a greater proportion of their resources to responding to the pandemic with very little or nothing available for other healthcare services such as sexual and reproductive health. This could increase the burden of disease in the continent and cause unacceptably high maternal and child mortality. The deaths of 823,000 children and 20,000 mothers each year could be averted through universal #breastfeeding. #UHC cannot be achieved without a commitment to save these lives by mobilizing to promote breastfeeding today. #UHCDay #UHCis
A strong health system and #UHC means that everybody who needs medical treatment, whether immediate or eventual, has access to care. Curative care means taking steps like #InvestinOxygen  #UHCis

Health starts before you get sick. Taking preventative measures such as consistent check-ups can catch illnesses before they progress. A strong health system will contribute to #UHC and preventive care.  #WorldUHCDay #UHCis

AU COVID-19 Response Fund to launch $300m fundraising to help tackle the effects of #COVID19.  Register now 👉🏻 https://t.co/4eGCLEhQEb or join the live event fundraiser Today at 4:00pm (GMT+3) on Youtube 👉🏻 https://t.co/kUga0KDTKM Facebook 👉🏻 https://t.co/8Z18BYI5W0 Twitter 👇🏻 https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1319870343566295040?s=19  #FactNotFear #AfricaResponds  #AfricaAgainstCOVID19

The AU COVID-19 Response Fund is a vehicle for the implementation of the continental strategy to combat the pandemic. The Fundraiser webinar will inform and solicit support and contributions from the African private sector, public and other partners, in order to ensure that the continent can respond effectively to this unprecedented global crisis.  The webinar is part of a programme of activities that aims to raise awareness of the AU COVID-19 Response Fund, to date, we have raised 44 million, we need your help to raise a further $300m USD to tackle the immediate effects of COVID-19 in Africa. The main objectives of the fund are to mitigate the social, economic and humanitarian impact of COVID-19 in all African countries; boost the capacity of the Africa CDC to support response to public health emergencies across the continent; and support the procurement and distribution of essential COVID-19 medical supplies.  One of the keynote speakers at the Fundraiser will be Cyril Ramaphosa, current Chairperson of the AU and President of the Republic of South Africa. In a call to action he said that “now is the time to come together as one continent to tackle the biggest health crisis of our generation.”  The event will be broadcast in the African Union working languages (Arabic, English, French and Portuguese). There will be interventions from a number of leaders as well as international artists. Date: 24 October 2020 Time: 4:00 PM (East Africa Time) / 1:00 PM (GMT)  For more information on the event and how to contribute, go to https://au.int/en/AUCOVID19ResponseFund  Key Speakers: -Cyril Ramaphosa, current Chairperson of the AU and President of the Republic of South Africa -H.E. Moussa Faki Mahamat, Chairperson of the African Union Commission (AUC) -Prof. Benedict O Oramah, Chairman of the Board of Trustees AU COVID-19 Response Fund -H.E. Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director General -Dr. John Nkengasong, Director, Africa CDC -Dr. Vera Songwe, Executive Secretary, UNECA -Dr. Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, AU Special Envoy

Do’s and Dont’s of Face Masks:  ✔ DO Clean hands with alcohol-based hand rub or soap and water before putting on a face mask  ✔ DO Reach above the nose, below the chin, and completely cover the mouth and nostrils  ✔ DO Be made of multiple layers of fabric that you can still breathe through such as bandanas, dish towels  ✔ DO, wash and thoroughly dry your fabric masks  ✗ DON’T not use surgical masks, as those are needed by health professionals!  ✗ DON’T Reuse single-use masks  ​  #TargetCOVID19 #GetTheFacts #AfricaResponds @OnebyOne2030 @AfricaCDC @WHOAFRO

There is currently no vaccine to prevent #COVID19. The best way to prevent illness is to minimize exposure. It spreads mainly from people in close contact (within 1 meter) and through respiratory droplets from an infected person's cough/sneeze.  Stay 1-2 meters apart  Wear a mask if you cannot maintain physical distance  #TargetCOVID19 #GetTheFacts #AfricaResponds @OnebyOne2030 @AfricaCDC World Health Organization African Region

Do’s and Dont’s of Face Masks:  ✔ DO Clean hands with alcohol-based hand rub or soap and water before putting on a face mask  ✔ DO Reach above the nose, below the chin, and completely cover the mouth and nostrils  ✔ DO Be made of multiple layers of fabric that you can still breathe through such as bandanas, dish towels  ✔ DO, wash and thoroughly dry your fabric masks  ✗ DON’T not use surgical masks, as those are needed by health professionals!  ✗ DON’T Reuse single-use masks  ​  #TargetCOVID19 #GetTheFacts #AfricaResponds @OnebyOne2030 @AfricaCDC @WHOAFRO

25th Weekly Press Briefing on Coronavirus Disease Outbreak  Background Information: The COVID-19 has spread to about 215 countries and territories with more than 23 million cases; and claimed more than 810,000 lives worldwide. Over 1.2million cases have been reported in all 55 African countries, with nearly 28,000 deaths.  Africa CDC is working with Member States to ensure appropriate response to the outbreak in countries to keep up the encouraging number of recoveries and the impressive public health measures adopted by governments across the continent so far.  Africa CDC weekly engagement with members of the media to share critical updates on the coordinated efforts by African Union Member States to implement the joint continental strategy in response to COVID-19.  It also highlights key steps taken to support other initiatives such as PACT, vaccine development and the saving lives, economies and livelihoods campaign  as countries transition through different stages of the pandemic.

ADDIS ABABA, ETHIOPIA, 16 JULY 2020. The Permanent Mission of Japan to the African Union has announced a donation of US$ 1 million by the Government of Japan to the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC).  The grant is for implementing the Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19. It will be used to strengthen the capacity of Africa CDC Regional Collaboration Centres so they can support effective and efficient communication and knowledge exchange on COVID-19 among Member States,  as well as to support infection prevention and control activities and improve clinical case management of COVID-19. Read More at https://africacdc.org/news-item/government-of-japan-supports-africas-joint-continental-strategy-for-covid-19-response/ https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1283735339945820171

GUIDANCE ON ENVIRONMENTAL DECONTAMINATION IN THE CONTEXT OF COVID-19  The document details basic decontamination principles and procedures that should be followed to decontaminate the physical environment in the context of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. Surface contamination and transmission risk all differ by the type of setting and the volume of people that frequent each setting (e.g. healthcare facilities, public transport, and other busy facilities/workplaces), even though the principles of environmental decontamination remain the same.  Download here: https://africacdc.org/download/guidance-on-environmental-decontamination-in-the-context-of-covid-19/ https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1277525310217555968 #FactsNotFear #AfricaResponds #COVID19

Revealing the toll of COVID-19: A technical package for Member States. https://bit.ly/316o7V6  This technical package supports national governments to enhance their outbreak surveillance and response planning. Establishing a system of Rapid Mortality Surveillance would inform national decision-making based on the true impact of COVID-19 within countries and communities.   This #COVID19 technical package contains step-by-step guidance on the collection, analysis and use of all-cause mortality data collected through facility- or community-based surveillance. It has been developed by Vital Strategies, in partnership with Africa CDC and others.

INTERIM GUIDANCE ON THE USE OF RAPID ANTIBODY TESTS FOR COVID-19 RESPONSE.  The speed of developing diagnostics for SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), has been quite remarkable. Diagnostics have focused on nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) to identify infected individuals in acute-phase disease for timely implementation of mitigation strategies and case management. More and more immunodiagnostics, mostly rapid diagnostic tests, are being made available as an alternative to NAATs. This type of test can be used out-of-laboratory conditions at large scale.  Download the document here 👉🏼: https://africacdc.org/download/interim-guidance-on-the-use-of-rapid-antibody-tests-for-covid-19-response/  https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1272809628133457920 #COVID19 #AfricaResponds #FactsNotFear

GUIDANCE ON EASING LOCKDOWN IN AFRICAN UNION MEMBER STATES  In response to the first cases of COVID-19 reported in Africa, many African Union Member States implemented large-scale public health and social measures rapidly.   These measures were aimed at reducing transmission and the number of new cases being reported, protecting the most vulnerable populations, and allowing time for countries to ramp up critical healthcare and diagnostic services.   While these quick actions bought time for Member States, the negative socio-economic impacts are being felt widely, and countries are now exploring how best to ease these measures back while still managing the outbreak.  https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1267001393052889089?s=19 Download: https://t.co/Yz3tNpobKA #FactsNotFear #AfricaResponds
To reduce your likelihood of becoming infected with #COVID19, try not to touch your face. Especially avoid touching your eyes, mouth, and nose. #AfricaResponds #FactNotFear

LA COMMISSION DE L'UNION AFRICAINE ANNONCE LE PROGRAMME DE LEADERSHIP AFRICA CDC - KOFI ANNAN POUR L'AFRIQUE   "L'Afrique est un continent résilient, mais nous avons besoin de systèmes de santé plus solides qui puissent aider les communautés à devenir plus résistantes. Le Kofi Annan Global Health Leadership est un programme visionnaire qui contribuera à fournir la capacité nécessaire pour répondre aux menaces de maladies sur le continent.   Africa CDC se félicite de ce programme très important, surtout à un moment où le monde lutte contre la pandémie de COVID-19 et fait progresser l'accord de libre-échange continental", a déclaré le Dr John Nkengasong, directeur du Africa CDC. Plus d'informations sur 👉🏽 https://africacdc.org/news-item/african-union-commission-announces-africa-cdc-kofi-annan-global-health-leadership-programme/

AFRICAN UNION COMMISSION ANNOUNCES AFRICA CDC KOFI ANNAN GLOBAL HEALTH LEADERSHIP PROGRAMME   “Africa is a resilient continent, but we need stronger health systems that can support communities to become more resilient. The Kofi Annan Global Health Leadership is a visionary programme that will help provide the capacity needed to respond to disease threats across the continent.   Africa CDC welcomes this very important programme especially at such a time that the world is fighting the COVID-19 pandemic and advancing the Continental Free Trade Agreement,” said Dr John Nkengasong, Director of Africa CDC.  More on 👉🏽 https://africacdc.org/news-item/african-union-commission-announces-africa-cdc-kofi-annan-global-health-leadership-programme/

There is currently no vaccine to prevent #COVID19. The best way to prevent illness is to minimize exposure. #COVID19 spreads mainly from people in close contact (within about 1-2 metres) & through respiratory droplets from an infected person's cough/sneeze  Observe #PhysicalDistancing in public places; at the office, market, public transport or at school to protect yourself and others.    #AfricaResponds #AfricaPrepares

DES CHERCHEURS AFRICAINS À LA TÊTE D'UNE COALITION SCIENTIFIQUE POUR DÉVELOPPER UN SYSTÈME DE SURVEILLANCE AFIN DE DÉTECTER LES PANDÉMIES ÉMERGENTES EN TEMPS RÉEL  Les chercheurs du Centre d'excellence africain pour la génomique des maladies infectieuses (ACEGID), de l'Université Redeemer, à Ede, au Nigeria, ont entamé un partenariat avec les Centres Africains de Prévention et de Contrôle des maladies (Africa CDC), le Broad Institute du MIT et de Harvard, et d'autres partenaires de la recherche et de la santé publique, afin de mettre en œuvre un projet Sentinel pour un système d'alerte précoce en Afrique.  "Le potentiel de Sentinel pour transformer la surveillance des maladies infectieuses en Afrique est sans limite, et sa mission est complémentaire à celle de Africa CDC: renforcer la surveillance et les interventions d'urgence, et améliorer la gestion des menaces pour la santé publique ayant des conséquences régionales et internationales", déclare John Nkengasong, directeur de Africa CDC.  Pour plus d'informations, visitez: https://africacdc.org/news-item/african-researchers-lead-scientific-coalition-developing-surveillance-system-for-detecting-emerging-pandemics-in-real-time/

AFRICAN RESEARCHERS LEAD SCIENTIFIC COALITION DEVELOPING SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR DETECTING EMERGING PANDEMICS IN REAL-TIME  Researchers at the African Center of Excellence for Genomics of Infectious Diseases (ACEGID), Redeemer’s University, Ede, Nigeria, have begun a partnership with the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, and other research and public health partners, to implement a Sentinel project for an early warning system in Africa.  “The potential of Sentinel to transform infectious disease surveillance in Africa is boundless, and its mission complements that of Africa CDC: to strengthen surveillance and emergency response, and improve management of public health threats of regional and international consequence,” says John Nkengasong, Director of the Africa CDC.   More information at: https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1259895540814434309  https://africacdc.org/news-item/african-researchers-lead-scientific-coalition-developing-surveillance-system-for-detecting-emerging-pandemics-in-real-time/

LES BESOINS EN PERSONNEL SOUMIS POUR LE SOUTIEN DES PARTENAIRES En tant qu'institution leader sur le continent dans la lutte contre COVID-19, Africa CDC avait prévu que l'épidémie de COVID-19 aurait inévitablement un impact sur l'Afrique et a travaillé activement avec les États membres et les partenaires de l'Union africaine sur la préparation et la réponse à la maladie sur le continent.  Dans le cadre des efforts visant à renforcer la réponse et la préparation de l'Afrique dans la lutte contre la pandémie de COVID-19, la Commission de l'Union africaine, par l'intermédiaire des Centres africains de contrôle et de prévention des maladies (Africa CDC), souhaite demander aux partenaires et aux institutions concernées dans le monde entier de soutenir ses activités en mettant à disposition le personnel identifié ci-dessous : Pour plus d'informations, visitez https://africacdc.org/download/critical-staffing-needs-for-support-by-partners/ https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1258755296492695554

CRITICAL STAFFING NEEDS FOR SUPPORT BY PARTNERS  As the lead institution on the continent in the fight against COVID-19, Africa CDC had anticipated that COVID-19 outbreak would inevitably impact Africa and has been working actively with African Union Member States and partners on preparedness and response to the disease in the continent.  As part of the efforts to strengthen Africa’s response and preparedness in combating the COVID-19 pandemic, the African Union Commission through the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) would like to request partners and concerned institutions around the globe to support its activities through the provision of the below identified staff: More information at https://africacdc.org/download/critical-staffing-needs-for-support-by-partners/  https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1258755296492695554

#COVID19: L'UNION AFRICAINE EN DISCUSSION AVEC LE MADAGASCAR SUR UN REMEDE A BASE DE PLANTES.  L'Union Africaine est en discussion avec la République de Madagascar, par le biais de son ambassade à Addis-Abeba, en vue d'obtenir des données techniques concernant la sécurité et l'efficacité d'un remède à base de plantes, récemment annoncé par Madagascar pour la prévention et le traitement du COVID19.  Une fois les détails fournis, Africa CDC examinera les données scientifiques recueillies sur l'innocuité et l'efficacité du COVID19 Organics. Cet examen sera basé sur les normes techniques et éthiques afin de recueillir les preuves scientifiques nécessaires concernant le remède.  https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1257680189942890496?s=19  # COVID19 #FactsNotFear #AfricaResponds

New report provides African governments real-time information and guidance to find the balance in COVID-19 response https://africacdc.org/news/new-report-provides-african-governments-real-time-information-and-guidance-to-find-the-balance-in-covid-19-response/

AFRICAN UNION IN DISCUSSIONS WITH MADAGASCAR OVER HERBAL REMEDY  The African Union is in discussion with the Republic of Madagascar, through its embassy in Addis Ababa, with a view to obtain technical data regarding the safety & efficiency of a herbal remedy, recently announced by Madagascar for the reported prevention & treatment of COVID19.  Once furnished with the details, Africa CDC will review the scientific data gathered on the safety & efficacy of the COVID19 Organics. This review will be based on global technical & ethical norms to garner the necessary scientific evidence regarding the performance of the tonic.  https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1257664572674236416?s=19  #COVID19 #FactsNotFear #AfricaResponds

The first United Nations “solidarity flight” left Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, yesterday from where it will transport vital medical cargo to all countries in Africa, where supplies are desperately needed to contain the spread of COVID-19.  “The medical supplies are timely as the continent still has a window of opportunity to fight the COVID-19 pandemic. Africa is extremely under resourced says Dr John Nkengasong, Director of Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)    https://twitter.com/i/status/1249230903777398785

GUIDANCE ON CONTACT TRACING FOR COVID-19 PANDEMIC  Contact tracing may help limit COVID-19 transmission when the first cases are identified within a country but can be very resource intensive. It is likely not to be feasible when community transmission is occurring and cases outside known transmission chains increase greatly. Member States are advised to use the characteristics of the epidemic in their country to decide when and how to do contact tracing (see Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention Recommendations for Stepwise Response to COVID-19). Lutte contre la Maladie à Virus #EBOLA en Afrique :  25 prestataires de laboratoire et acteurs de la santé publique de la RDC, de la République du Congo, de l’Angola, du Gabon, de la Tanzanie, de la Zambie, du Sud Soudan, Rwanda, Burundi et de l'Ouganda améliorent leurs connaissances dans le diagnostic du virus EBOLA grâce à une formation organisée par Africa CDC avec le soutien de l'INRB, l'IMT/Anvers, l'IRD/Montpellier, l'UNMC, l'OMS, du CDC Atlanta et de l'IPD. Le professeur MUYEMBE, Directeur de l'INRB, a appelé à davantage de soutien et de ressources pour qu’Africa CDC continuent à aider les États membres de l' African Union.   Reportage de B One Télévision

Africa CDC is working closely with partners to scale up emergency preparedness among #AU member states and provide technical support especially in laboratory confirmation of the #COVID2019. 13 member states are represented at the 2nd round of Laboratory Diagnosis training organized by Africa CDC in partnership with the NICD in South Africa.

#Kinshasa  Official launching ceremony of the Africa CDC international training on laboratory diagnosis of the #Ebola virus disease: the Director of Africa CDC, Dr. John Nkengasong, welcomes the implementation of the agreements reached at the GOMA Ministerial meeting on, inter alia, capacity building of health care providers in the countries of the Great Lakes region in the context of enhanced cross-border collaboration and health security against the EBOLA virus disease.

The vision of excellence in medical research, surveillance, and training of the Institut National de Recherche Biomédicale in Central Africa is being realized on 20 February 2020 through the inauguration of its new modern research complex. In front of an audience of local and international partners, the coordinator of the #INRB, Professor #MUYEMBE expressed his gratitude to the #Japanese government who made the implementation of this project a reality. To his long-standing partners such as #AFRICACDC and #WHO, represented at this meeting by their respective directors, the Director of the INRB directed his thanks and saluted their contribution in the improvement of the quality of health in the #DRC.

As of today, 7th February 2020, there is still NO confirmed case of Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) in #Africa.  Countries awaiting lab results are Ethiopia, Kenya, Namibia, South Sudan. If people want reliable information they should go to the WHO website https://www.who.int/ or the Africa CDC website africacdc.org/ that will help.  There is no need to panic at this point but rather to base action & reaction on the fact & evidence. #Coronavirus #2019nCoV #FactsNotFear

China-Africa Ties: China's efforts to medicine in Africa  China's focus on sharing covers not only Asia, but also the global environment. China is determined to assist the African continent with its public health systems. Beijing has committed 80 million dollars for the Africa Centers for Disease Control, tasked with timely responses to health emergencies. Coletta Wanjohi reports from Addis Ababa.  At the African Union headquarters in Addis Ababa Ethiopia, health experts monitor the situation reports from different regions within Africa. It's a major component of the Africa Centre for Disease control that was launched by the African Union in 2017. The main aim is to support all African countries to improve surveillance, emergency response, and prevention of infectious diseases.  DR. JOHN NKENGASONG, DIRECTOR AFRICA CENTRES FOR DISEASE CONTROL "We have staff over 65 staff available not just at the headquarters but at the some of the regional centres including Zambia and Kenya. And our hope is that by the end of the year the other centers in Nigeria , Egypt and Gabon will also go operations."  The outbreak of the Ebola virus, in West Africa in 2016 was seen by the continent as a wake up call to reinforce its public health systems to combat future threats. And China has now stepped in with additional cash to keep the centre funded.  DR. JOHN NKENGASONG, DIRECTOR AFRICA CENTRES FOR DISEASE CONTROL "I was just in China in January with the chairperson of the AU and some commissioner to continue the dialogue on how China can work with us and they are committing up to 80 million dollars for the construction of Africa CDC and other regional Centres, that is key."  China is also offering its expertise and is securing its influence on the African continent.  EBBA KALONDO, SPOKESPERSON CHAIR OF THE AFRICAN UNION COMMISSION "Partnership with China and the African continent is historically important and becomes more important as the South – South partnership frameworks become more important within the new global contexts."  COLETTA WANJOHI ADDIS ABABA, ETHIOPIA "A team from the China Centre for Disease Control recently visited the health experts at the AU commission in Addis Ababa , to discuss how China can be of further assistance to ensure the establishment of a fully fledged emergency response mechanism within the continent.  For now, the Africa CDC is tapping from existing medical expertise within the continent. It wants to introduce scholarships for medical personnel within the universities in Africa, to sharpen their skills and strengthen the continent's much needed public health response system. Coletta Wanjohi, CGTN, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

In his opening address to a joint technical meeting on #Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) held at the African Union Commission (AUC) headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on 21 and 22 February 2019, he assured participants of AUC’s commitment to creating synergies for controlling and preventing the spread of EVD across the continent. CONSULTATIVE MEETING ON Africa CDC PUBLIC HEALTH SITUATION ROOM...  20 February 2019, Addis Ababa. From 19 to 20 February 2019, representatives of African UnionUnion Member States met at the African Union Commission headquarters in Addis Ababa to discuss how to establish an Africa CDC #Health_Situation_Room that will connect health information systems from different African countries.  The Situation Room is a software application developed by UNAIDS, which directly accesses HIV/AIDS information systems within Member States and produces flexible and readily comprehensible reports for decision-making by health officials.  “The Situation Room is a concept which UNAIDS initiated to make data revolution a reality in the AIDS response. We want to take the initiative forward in driving data for improving health in the whole continent,” said #Taavi_Erkkola from UNIADS. Read more: http://africacdc.org/press-centre/news/83-consultative-meeting-on-africa-cdc-public-health-situation-room

Africa CDC, Bill and Melinda @gatesfoundation and @AFENETafrica convene a 2-day Technical Workshop on #Mortality #Surveillance in Africa at the African Union HQ in Addis Ababa with a call for Member States to suggest tangible ways to solve issues of Mortality data across  the continent.  The purpose of this meeting is to bring together Member State experts on vital statistics, subject matter experts, and partners to provide input into the design and targets of the Africa CDC Mortality Surveillance programme.  Specific Objectives of this Meeting are to:  a) Review mortality surveillance landscape across Africa, including civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS); b) Raise awareness about innovative approaches to mortality surveillance that can complement CRVS; c) Present proposal for Africa CDC #MortalitySurveillanceProgramme and solicit feedback from Member States and Partners;  d) Agree on general content of, working groups for, and timeline to develop an Africa CDC #Framework for Mortality Surveillance.  https://twitter.com/AfricaCDC/status/1100322413395537920

RISLNET Central Africa Bureau Holds First Meeting...  Bureau members of the Regional Integrated Surveillance and Laboratory Network (RISLNET) Central Africa met in Libreville, Gabon, from 4 to 7 February 2019 to review their roles and responsibility and discuss plans for 2019.  “This meeting is to review progress on implementation in 2018, discuss the work plan for 2019 and review the roles and responsibilities of bureau members,” said Dr Mohammed Abdulaziz, RISLNET Programme Officer and Medical Epidemiologist at Africa CDC.  It was the first meeting of the bureau since their election in November 2018 and it was attended by all the six elected bureau members and representatives of the Gabon Ministry of Health, African Union Commission, Africa CDC, Pandora Alert and Global Health Systems Solution (GHSS).  For more information, contact:    http://africacdc.org/press-centre/news/81-rislnet-central-africa-bureau-holds-first-meeting-2  About the Africa CDC…  The Africa CDC mission is to strengthen Africa’s public health institution’s capacities, capabilities and partnerships to detect and respond quickly and effectively to disease threats and outbreaks based on science, policy, and data-driven interventions and programmes.

Message of the Director of Africa CDC, Dr #John_Nkengasong...  Two years ago, on January 31, 2017, African Heads of States and Governments officially launched the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (#AfricaCDC) as a Specialized Technical Institution of the African Union (AU). The resolution to establish a new continental African public health agency was visionary and timely as the continent strives to achieve the health goals stated in its #Agenda2063, which is a road map for Africa’s growth and development. The Agenda calls for robust integrated systems to significantly reduce communicable and non-communicable diseases. Importantly, Africa is at a pivotal moment as its moves towards greater integration including the single African air transport market by the AU to open up the continent's skies; the African continental free trade agreement; and the free movement of people across borders. These initiatives are powerful boosters to economic growth but also have significant public health implications.  As such in order to adequately position the continent to meet the public challenges that will be associated with the economic and political integration of the continent, we are calling for #ANewPublicHealthOrder that focuses on: 1) advocating for and strengthening members state’s national public health institutes, 2) establishing Regional Integrated Surveillance and Laboratory Networks in order to pool all available public health assets that exist in each geographic region, 3) invest in public health workforce development, 4) advocate and enhance the culture of data acquisition, storage, timely use, and sharing, 5) developing public private partnerships, and 6) enhanced coordination of partners and donors efforts to align with the Agenda 2063 for health.  As summarized in the 2018 annual report, #Africa_CDC continued to make remarkable progress in its implementation and set up as well as support for Member States to prevent and control disease. At Africa CDC we are remain mindful of the fact that “Progress is not in enhancing what is, but in advancing toward what will be” Khalil Gibran.  In #Year2019, Africa CDC will continue to provide strategic direction and promote public health practice within African Union Member States through capacity building, minimization of health inequalities, promoting continuous quality improvement in the delivery of public health services as well in the prevention of public health emergencies and threats, through partnerships, science, policy, and data-driven interventions and programs. COMMUNIQUE DE PRESSE Mission #ASEDCO #EbolaRDC Nord-Kivu : Africa CDC en ordre de bataille contre le virus EBOLA à #KALUNGUTA, nouveau foyer épidémique. Aux côtés du Ministère de la Santé RDC, de l’Organisation Mondiale de la Santé et de plusieurs autres partenaires dans la lutte contre la 10ème  épidémie de la maladie à Virus Ebola, les Centres Africains de Contrôle et Prévention des Maladies (AFRICA CDC) étendent leurs tentacules dans la riposte menée au Nord-Kivu et en Ituri. A environ vingt jours depuis la notification des premiers cas dans la Zone de Santé de #_Kalunguta, Territoire de Beni, gestionnaires d’alerte, épidémiologistes et socio anthropologues travaillant pour le compte d’AFRICA CDC prêtent mains forte sur le terrain. Entre flambée des cas et réticence communautaire, ils intensifient des efforts pour contenir la chaîne de contagion virale.  En effet, cette zone de santé a connu une surmorbidité et surmortalité que l’on ne peut accepter pour peu que l’on aime où ou que l’on respecte la vie. Voilà pourquoi la synergie des efforts a amené tous les partenaires et le Ministère à descendre sur le lieu reculer la MVE. Aujourd’hui, avec 21 cas notifiés dont 8 internés au CTE et 13 décès y compris les probables, plus de 300 contacts engendrés sont suivis quotidiennement par les relais communautaires, civils comme militaires, supervisés par un épidémiologiste, volontaire d’AFRICA CDC.  Pour faciliter leur travail, ils ont été dotés d’outils constitués essentiellement de thermo flashs, fiches pour définition des cas ainsi que des boots et imperméables pour faire face aux intempéries. Ils bénéficient également des séances de briefing et débriefing qui contribuent activement à l’optimisation des résultats. Une fois un cas suspect détecté, l’alerte est remontée au niveau de la sous-coordination de Butembo qui gère la contrée pour des raisons d’accès, ; l’axe Beni-Kalunguta étant impraticable.  Dans le souci d’outiller davantage les acteurs sociaux impliqués dans cette lutte acharnée contre la maladie à virus Ebola, le socio anthropologue d’AFRICA CDC a sensibilisé sur la nécessité de l’engagement communautaire et les tactiques à développer relativement aux réalités sociologiques de la contrée.  Une option capitale dans le combat mené contre les rumeurs, des goulots d’étranglement pour la riposte.  Identifié comme zone rouge suite aux récurrentes incursions des rebelles MAI-MAI, Kalunguta a reçu un cas confirmé de Beni ayant échappé aux équipes de la riposte. Après des négociations avec les leaders du village, une mission d’investigation a été organisée pour examiner la flambée des cas. Cette investigation avait permis d’identifier les causes et activer le plan de contingence pour ce nouveau foyer épidémique. En dépit de quelques réticences, dont la dernière en date a été enregistrée le 13 Novembre 2018 (où les agents commis à la riposte ont reçu des coups et blessures de l’essor de la thanatologie   dans l’Aire de Santé de   KANYIUNGA),  les habitants du village se sont montrés coopératifs et la vaccination se poursuit avec le concours de la Police Nationale Congolaise et des Forces Armées de la RDC. Il y a lieu de signaler que dans ce coin de la province, un grand mouvement des malades et des contacts est observé de Beni vers Butembo.  Ces déplacements mettent à l’épreuve la dynamique classique de contrôle de l’épidémie et émousse tous les efforts inlassables et persévérants conjugués par les équipes de riposte dans le contrôle de la MVE d’une part et d’autre part la population non encore bien engagée fait souvent heurter les acteurs de la riposte aux ardeurs de leurs forces.  A noter qu’en plus de Kalunguta, l’Union Africaine par son Agence Spécialisée AFRICA CDC déploie ses volontaires à travers les villes de Butembo, Masereka, Beni, Goma, Lubero et Tchomia. Une équipe mixte constituée d’épidémiologistes, techniciens de laboratoire, experts en prévention et contrôle des infections, communicologues et socio-anthropologues. Sur terrain, ils mettent tout ce qui est à leur pouvoir pour arrêter la circulation du virus d’Ebola en adéquation entre autre avec l’appel du SG des nations unies: ’’Des infiniment petits appelés virus d’Ebola voyagent clandestinement sans passeports ni visas et ne respectent pas les limites des frontières. Aucune Zone de santé du Nord Kivu n’est vraiment pas en sûreté. Tant que la porte sera ouverte, le Nord Kivu sera toujours envahit’’.

Africa CDC / AFENET Scientific Manuscript Writing Workshop for technical staff of National Public Health Institutes of African Union Member States. #ScientificWritingWorkshop2018  As part of efforts to strengthen the culture of public health research among NPHIs in Member States, and preliminary steps to operationalizing a research component of Africa CDC’s NPHI and research pillar, Africa CDC in collaboration with the African Field Epidemiology Network is organizing a scientific writing workshop targeted at technical staff of NPHIs in selected Member States. The Workshop will take place from 26 - 30 November, 2018 in Kampala, #Uganda. #ScientificWritingWorkshop2018.  The #overall aim of the #ScientificWritingWorkshop2018 is to support the NPHIs in developing a culture of operational research to provide scientific evidence and solutions to public health challenges on the continent.   Expected #outputs of the workshop are:  Finalized manuscripts ready for publication in peer reviewed journals at the end of the workshop,  Guidance document on setting up of a research unit in Africa CDC that is able to collaborate and coordinate priority public health research in Africa through the RCC, and  Database of the network of mentors, researchers within NPHIs and potential donors.  #PARTICIPANTS to the Workshop are Africa CDC Experts, facilitators from AFENET and Thirty technical staff of NPHIs from Member States. The technical staff of NPHIs will be represented from Liberia, Sierra Lone, Mozambique, Zambia, South Africa, Kenya, Ethiopia, Uganda, Cameroon, Gabon, DRC, Nigeria, Egypt, and Tunisia (Selection based on countries with existing NPHI, host of RCC and ensuring regional spread).   Co-organized by @Africa CDC & @AFENETAfrica, the workshop intends strengthening the culture of PH research among NPHIs in Member States and setting up of a research unit in @AfricaCDC that is able to collaborate and coordinate priority PH research in Africa through the RCCs.  In his introductory message on behalf of Africa CDC Director, Dr Mohammed Abdullaziz wished the participants of the workshop to be the first contributors to the #AfricaCDC_journal. He also emphasized the partnership between Africa CDC and AFENETAfrica and the role of #NPHIs in operationalizing the research component of AfricaCDC’s strategic plan. #ScientificWritingWorkshop2018. @JNkengasong @AFENETAfrica African Union

Riposte à la Maladie à Virus Ebola en République Démocratique du Congo : L'Union Africaine, par l'intermédiaire des Centres Africains de Contrôle et de Prévention des Maladies, déploie la deuxième cohorte des volontaires experts...

Africa CDC soutient la coordination de la lutte contre #Ebola à Butembo...  Une équipe mixte d'Epidémiologistes, Médecins cliniciens, Experts en prévention et controle de l’infection, Experts en communication etBiologistes d'Africa CDC vient en appui à la coordination de la lutte contre Ebola de la ville de Butembo. Située à 79,6 km de la ville de #Mangina, épicentre de la maladie à virus Ebola dans la Province du Nord-Kivu, la ville de Butembo a signalé le premier cas confirmé d'Ebola le mardi 4 septembre 2018. Arrivés à Butembo le mercredi 5 septembre 2018, sur  demande du Directeur Général de la Direction Générale de lutte contre la maladie, les volontaires d’Africa CDC menent leurs activités dans le cadre du soutien de l'Union Africaine AfricanUnion à la réponse internationale à l’épidémie d'Ebola.  Les tâches auxquelles les volontaires se sont attelées dès leur arrivée sont suivantes : investigation des alertes, prospection des sites d'installation des centres de traitement Ebola, évaluation des besoins en matière de prévention et de contrôle de l’infection et le listage des  contacts autour du cas confirmé.  Quatre enquêtes ont été menées le jeudi 6 septembre 2018 dans les zones de santé de Vutsundo, Kyangike et Kirinda. Trois structures de santé ont été prospectées et vingt contacts listés.  A ce jour, les volontaires d'Africa CDC couvrent quatre commissions principales de la coordination de lutte contre Ebola de Butembo: Surveillance épidémiologique, Prévention, Laboratoire et communication. Africa CDC est l'une des premières organisations à arriver à Butembo 24 heures après la notification du premier cas positif d'Ebola  dans cette ville de la province du Nord-Kivu. #ANewPublicHealthOrder #TousContreEbola

Lilongwe, 13 August 2018 – The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) organized the Regional Cholera Strategy Technical working group meeting from 08 to 10 August 2018. The meeting aimed at developing a Cholera Strategy for the Southern Africa Development Committee (SADC) region brought together Cholera Focal points from the eleven (11) SADC Member States and was facilitated by the Africa CDC through its Southern Africa Regional Collaborating Centre (RCC).  During his opening remarks, Dr Storn Kabuluzi, Director of the Public Health Institute of Malawi (PHIM) highlighted that the challenges faced by the Southern African Member States are similar and require a collaborative approach to overcome them. He also emphasized on how developing a Regional Cholera Strategy will address these challenges with a clear roadmap to prevent and control cholera outbreaks in Southern Africa countries and this will go a long way in helping member states realize that they can kick cholera out of the region.  The Africa CDC in collaboration with the SADC identified strategic areas of collaboration between the two Institutes for short-term interventions including development of a Regional Cholera Strategy based on emerging issues affect more than one Member States in the region. The Regional Cholera Technical working group has been tasked to address all cholera related activities within the SADC region including developing work plans and coordinate cholera specific activities within the region.  For more information, visit  www.africacdc.org - www.au.int/africacdc  Or contact: Ms. Chimwemwe Waya Public Health Officer, Africa CDC Southern RCC Plot 13, Reedbuck Road, Kabulonga Lusaka, Zambia, WayaC@africa-union.org - AfricaCDC@africa-union.org

Statement of the Chairperson of the African Union Commission on the end of the Ebola Outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo.  Addis Ababa, 26 July 2018: The Chairperson of the Commission of the African Union, HE.Moussa Faki Mahamat welcomes the official announcement by the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo #DRC, on 24 July 2018, of the end of the #Ebola virus outbreak in the country. He commends the Congolese Government for its swift and effective response since the outbreak was declared on 8 May 2018 in the province of Equateur. The last case that tested negative was 42 days ago. This, as per the World Health Organization guidelines and International Health Regulations, marks the end of the outbreak.  The Chairperson of the Commission notes that the timely declaration of the outbreak, in accordance with the International Health Regulations, as well as the leadership and pro-activeness demonstrated by the Congolese Government, allowed a coordinated and efficient intervention of all concerned partners to swiftly contain the outbreak. The African Union Commission, through the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), has made a significant contribution to the efforts aimed at containing the outbreak, in support of the Congolese-led response. The #AfricaCDC deployed health personnel in the affected areas, trained more than 300 local experts, procured diagnostic equipment, and supported the DRC Ministry of Health in central coordination of the response at national level.  The African Union will continue to support the efforts of the Congolese Government during the 90-day period of enhanced surveillance following the official end of the Ebola outbreak.  #NOTE_TO_EDITORS: The Ministry of Health of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) declared the end of the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) outbreak in Equateur province on 24 July 2018, after sustained national-led efforts to contain it within the affected areas. This outbreak spread across three health zones, namely Bikoro, Iboko and Wangata in the Equateur Province, resulting in a total of 54 confirmed cases, with 33 EVD-related deaths.  On 8 May 2018, the Ministry of Health of the DRC declared a new outbreak of the EVD in the Bikoro health zone. This was the 9th outbreak of EVD over the past four decades in the country.  Following the declaration of the outbreak, the African Union (#AU) Commission, through the Africa Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), took a number of steps to contribute to the Government-led response. These included the following: i. activation of its Emergency Operational Centre (#EOC) to monitor and coordinate the AU response from the Headquarters; ii. deployment of an advanced team of two epidemiologists within 48 hours following the outbreak, to support the Congolese Government efforts; iii. deployment of 37 staff both at Headquarters and to the field, including 21 surveillance experts in the affected health zones, as part of the Government-led response; iv. training of 320 local experts in the DRC, namely 50 laboratory experts in diagnosis of EVD, 50 officers on surveillance and disease intelligence disease, and 220 border health officials on border screening and monitoring, as part of the strengthening of the national health system; v. procurement of six laboratory diagnostic (#Genexpert) machines and 2,000 cartridges (testing kits) for a total of US$ 147,000 to be donated to the Government to support diagnosis of Ebola virus diseases and other outbreak diseases; and vi. support to the DRC Ministry of Health in central coordination of the response at national level.  https://au.int/en/pressreleases/20180726/statement-chairperson-african-union-commission-end-ebola-outbreak-democratic

Deuxième réunion du Conseil Consultatif et Technique Des Centres Africains de Contrôle et de Prévention des Maladies (Africa CDC)   Addis Abéba, 02 juillet 2018 - La Deuxième réunion du Conseil Consultatif et Technique du CDC Afrique se tiendra du 04 au 05 juillet 2018 à Addis Abéba, Ethiopie, au siège de la Commission de l'Union Africaine. Le rôle du Conseil Consultatif et Technique du CDC Afrique est de donner des orientations sur les questions émergentes et d'autres questions connexes de contrôle et de prévention des maladies. Il fournit aussi des conseils sur les plans stratégiques et les activités du CDC Afrique ; le plaidoyer et la mobilisation des ressources. En outre, le Conseil fournit des orientations sur différents aspects de la surveillance, la détection et la réponse aux maladies sur le continent africain. En plus, il donne un aperçu des domaines de recherche et d'étude et des mérites du travail scientifique du CDC Afrique. Le CDC Afrique a été officiellement lancé le 31 janvier 2017 en marge de la 28ème Session Ordinaire. En mars 2017, le CDC Afrique a tenu sa première réunion du Conseil Consultatif et Technique et a également lancé son plan stratégique quinquennal. Au cours de cette réunion, les points suivants ont été convenus :  i) la composition des membres du Conseil Consultatif et Technique ; ii) L’élection des dirigeants du Conseil ; iii) L’adoption du Règlement intérieur du Conseil d’administration et du Conseil Consultatif et Technique du CDC Afrique.   Les objectifs de cette deuxième réunion du Conseil Consultatif et Technique sont les suivants : 1. Obtenir une mise à jour détaillée sur les progrès du CDC Afrique depuis la dernière réunion. 2. Fournir des conseils dans les domaines techniques programmatiques spécifiques du CDC Afrique.  Pour plus d'informations : Visitez : www.africacdc.org - www.au.africa/africacdc   Ou contactez:    Dr Promesse Chrys Kaniki  | Communications & information Officer | Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention | African Union Commission I E-mail: KanikiC@africa-union.org | Tel: +251 909 537 791 Dr Sheila Tamara SHAWA | Senior Project Officer | Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention | African Union Commission I E-mail: ShawaS@africa-union.org | Tel: +251 92 273 6987  A propos du CDC Afrique Le CDC Afrique aide tous les pays africains à améliorer la surveillance, les interventions d'urgence et la prévention des maladies infectieuses. Il s'agit notamment de faire face aux épidémies, aux catastrophes naturelles et d'origine humaine, ainsi qu'aux événements de santé publique d'intérêt régional et international. Il cherche en outre à renforcer la capacité de réduire la charge de morbidité sur le continent.

Africa CDC deploys epidemiologists to respond to the Ebola epidemic.  Urges long term action to build resilient health systems locally and national public health systems to pick up events rapidly   Kinshasa/Bandaka/Bikoro, 20 May 2018 - The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention has recruited 25 #epidemiologists to support the team working at the #epicentre of the #Ebola affected districts in Bandaka and Bikoro in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Following the announcement on 8 May 2018 of the Ebola outbreak by the authorities, the Africa CDC deployed an assessment mission within 48 hours. The Africa CDC’s Emergency Operational Centre was activated within hours to link, scan and monitor the situation.    “The nascent Africa CDC is improving its response capacity and has responded to 9 outbreaks over one year and in the case of the current Ebola outbreak much more swiftly. Africa needs to bring its existing public health assets together in order to work seamlessly and respond swiftly. To address the global health security agenda in Africa we need long term action to build resilient health systems locally and national public health systems to pick up events rapidly” said Dr. John Nkengasong, the Director of the Africa CDC.   The Africa CDC team which is now embedded in the national response team assisted the Government and partners to finalise the laboratory response strategy that is now under implementation. The Africa CDC is also supporting with the development of strategies for surveillance and contact tracing and the establishment of three health cordon zones to contain the virus. The Africa CDC will provide up to USD 2 Million to support Africa CDC interventions.   Due to the remote nature of the Equateur Province, it is expected that more efforts will need to be put in supply chain issues to ensure that essential items needed are delivered swiftly. Last week the African Union Peace and Security Council was briefed on the situation and will continue to receive reports.  Under Article 6(f) relating to its mandate with regard to humanitarian action and disaster management the Council can authorise deployment of military and civilian missions and assets to tackle emergency situations as it did in August 2014 in the Ebola outbreak in the West Africa sub-region.   This outbreak is the 9th outbreak of the Ebola virus disease over the last 4 decades in the country. The affected health area of Bikoro covers 1 075 km and has a population of 163 065 inhabitants. This huge population is supported by only 3 hospitals and 19 health centres, most of which have limited functionality.     The DRC government is working with partners to improve coordination mechanisms, enhance surveillance, laboratory confirmation, contact identification and follow-up, case management, infection prevention and control, safe and dignified burials, social mobilisation and community engagement, logistics, risk communication, vaccination, partner engagement, research and resource mobilisation.   The risk is high at national level and moderate in the region due in part to the proximity of the epidemic focus to the Congo River, the existence of a border with the Republic of Congo and the river which links with the capitals of the Republic of Congo and the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Central African Republic.
