A #New_outbreak of #Ebola_Virus_Disease in #DrCongo:  The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention Emergency Operation Center (#AfricaCDC_EOC) Support to the Government of Democratic Republic of Congo in The Fight Against The Ongoing Ebola Virus Outbreak in Bikoro.  Addis Ababa, 09 May 2018 A new outbreak of Ebola Virus Disease (#EVD) was declared on 08 May 2018 by the Government of Democratic Republic of Congo after two samples tested positive for EVD in Bikoro, Equateur Province.  Following the notification from the provincial Health Authorities on 03 May 2018, the Ministry of Health, with the support of African and international partners, deployed teams of experts to the affected province and localities to investigate and verify the outbreak. The Ministry of Health is currently establishing coordination mechanisms to mount an effective outbreak response. The latest report from the Ministry of Health, as of 08 May 2018, indicates a total of 21 suspected hemorrhagic cases with 17 related deaths. Two laboratory confirmed cases of EVD were also reported from the Equator provincial health zone.  In response to this new Ebola Virus Disease outbreak, the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (#AfricaCDC) has: a) activated its Emergency Operation Center (#EOC) to support national outbreak response efforts; b) mobilized its Epidemic Response Team (#ERT) for imminent deployment - the team is comprised of experts with previous experience in responding to the EVD outbreaks in West Africa in 2014 and Democratic Republic of Congo in 2017; c) set aside USD 250,000 for outbreak response activities whilst more resources are being mobilized.  The African Union Commission has been informed of the outbreak and is ready to offer comprehensive support of all AU organs to the response.  Africa CDC recognizes the vast experience and leadership role of the Government of Democratic Republic of Congo in dealing with previous EVD outbreaks. Africa CDC will facilitate a comprehensive and well-coordinated response involving all partners and stakeholders in mitigating this new EVD outbreak.  About the Africa CDC: The Africa CDC mission is to strengthen Africa’s public health institution’s capacities, capabilities and partnerships to detect and respond quickly and effectively to disease threats and outbreaks based on science, policy, and data-driven interventions and programmes. Learn more at: http://www.africacdc.org

Southern @AfricaCDC RCC and @ASLM_News (African Society for Laboratory Medicine) Member States meeting on strengthening Laboratory Systems and Networks for Surveillance. #Lusaka, Zambia, 02-04May 2018. @JNkengasong @_AfricanUnion

Southern @AfricaCDC RCC and @ASLM_News (African Society for Laboratory Medicine) Member States meeting on strengthening Laboratory Systems and Networks for Surveillance.  #Opening_speech by the Honourable MINISTER OF HEALTH, Dr #CHITALU_CHILUFYA MP, MCC.  02-04 May, 2018 Taj Pamodzi Hotel, Lusaka, Zambia  Representatives from  Africa CDC Headquarters  Africa CDC Southern Africa Regional Collaborating Centre Africa Society for Laboratory Medicine (ASLM) Regional member states (Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe, Invited guests, Members of the Press, Ladies and Gentlemen,  I wish to express my sincere gratitude to all of you present here for taking time from your busy schedules to be part of this important meeting.   I would also like to express my sincere gratitude to Africa CDC Secretariat from AU headquarters in Addis Ababa, Africa CDC Southern Africa RCC, the Zambia National Public Health Institute (ZNPHI) and our partners ASLM for the overall organisation and coordination of this meeting.  As you may be aware, Africa CDC is an African-owned institution newly established to address priority public health emergencies in Africa in a timely and effective manner. Endorsed by the African Heads of State and Government in January 2016, this Specialised Agency was officially launched in January 2017. Africa CDC has a continental mission to strengthen capacities, capabilities and partnerships in Africa’s public health institutions. This will enable them to detect and respond efficiently to disease threats, outbreaks and other public health events based on science, policy and data-driven interventions and programs.  With its headquarters at the African Union Commission in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, the Africa CDC works through five regional collaborating centres in Zambia (Southern region), Kenya (Eastern region), Egypt (Northern region), Nigeria (Western region) and Gabon (Central region). At country level this is operationalised through National Public Health Institutes (NPHIs).  Ladies and Gentlemen  Lusaka, Zambia is the seat of Africa CDC Southern Africa RCC and that is why we are gathered here as regional member states. The purpose of our meeting is to identify, prioritise and agree on effective measures for strengthening our national and regional laboratory systems, improving laboratory quality standards and promoting networks and linkages for services and resource sharing.  We are all aware of the strong need for comprehensive and quality laboratory services and networks in the diagnosis, management and control of diseases and outbreaks that occur within the region and beyond. Recently our region has experienced a number of outbreaks including Listeriosis in South Africa, and Cholera in Malawi, Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe. The laboratory has played a vital role in confirming and monitoring these outbreaks for effective management.   However, gaps still exist in laboratory capacities at country and regional level, particularly for molecular diagnostics such as PCR and gene sequencing which are essential for characterisation of disease-causing agents. In the spirit of regional integration, there is therefore a need to map laboratory assets and leverage on existing capabilities within the region. Laboratory capacity exists at various levels and in different sectors including human health, animal health, agriculture, and environment; all these need to be harnessed in the spirit of “One-Health”. Strong national and regional laboratory networks for specimen referral, resource sharing, and training are essential to actualise this aspiration.   Ladies and gentlemen  The Southern Africa RCC will lead in coordinating and cementing of linkages among public health laboratories in the region. As the host country of the RCC, Zambia is committed at the highest leadership level to safeguarding healthcare. With the unwavering support of His Excellency the President of the Republic of Zambia, Mr. Edgar Chagwa Lungu, I wish to reaffirm the Zambian Government’s continued commitment to ensuring that our RCC is adequately supported and functional.   As Minister of Health, I am resolved to ensuring the establishment of an efficient and effective surveillance and disease intelligence system that is supported by a high quality National Public Health Laboratory system.   I have no doubt that all of you experts in this meeting will activate the formation of strong networks at personal, institutional, country and regional levels, thereby enriching Africa’s capacity to effectively diagnose and monitor public health threats.   I look forward to successful deliberations over the next three days, with concrete agreed-upon action points for the benefit of our countries and the Southern African region at large.  It is now my singular honour and privilege to declare this meeting officially open.   I thank you.  ***************  The meeting is held in #Lusaka, #Zambia from 02 to 04 May 2018 and will convenes representatives from the Ministries of Health from the ten regional African Union Member States, namely; Republic of Angola, Republic of Botswana, Republic of Malawi, Republic of Mozambique, Kingdom of Lesotho, Republic of Namibia, Republic of South Africa, Kingdom of Swaziland, Republic of Zambia and Republic of Zimbabwe. #LabAfricaCDC2018 #Southern_AfricaCDC_RCC

Réunion Africa CDC et @ASLM_News (Société Africaine de Médecine de Laboratoire):  L' #Objectif est de tenir une réunion régionale en #Afrique_Australe dans le but d'identifier, prioriser et préconiser des mesures efficaces pour renforcer les systèmes de laboratoires nationaux et régionaux, améliorer leurs normes de qualité et promouvoir les réseaux et les liens pour le partage régional des services de laboratoire.  Plus précisément, la réunion va: 1. Discuter et convenir d'un #cadre pour les plans stratégiques des laboratoires nationaux; 2. Plaider pour et obtenir l'adhésion des pays pour mettre en œuvre la cartographie de laboratoire dans: 2.1. Premiers laboratoires de haut niveau (santé publique, laboratoires de référence et régionaux) du Centre de Collaboration Régionale (#CCR) dans le cadre du Réseau de Surveillance  de la Résistance aux Antimicrobiens (#AMRSNET) et du Réseau Régional de Surveillance et de Laboratoires (#RISLNET); et 2.2. Par la suite à travers l'ensemble du réseau national de laboratoire pour soutenir le système de laboratoire renforcement des activités. 3. Identifier et discuter des moyens de renforcer les réseaux de laboratoires nationaux et régionaux existants et s'assurer qu'ils sont connectés à leurs réseaux régionaux respectifs.  La réunion se tiendra à #Lusaka, #Zambie du 02 au 04 mai 2018 et conviera des représentants des Ministères de la Santé des dix États membres de l'African Union de la Région australe, à savoir: la République d'Angola, la République du Botswana, la République du Malawi, la République du Mozambique, le Royaume du Lesotho, la République de Namibie, la République d'Afrique du Sud, le Royaume du Swaziland, la République de la Zambie et la République du Zimbabwe. #LabAfricaCDC2018 #Southern_AfricaCDC_RCC

Africa CDC and @ASLM_News (African Society for Laboratory Medicine) meeting:  The #Objective is to conduct a regional meeting in #Southern_Africa with the purpose of identifying, prioritising and advocating for effective measures for strengthening national and regional laboratory systems, improving their quality standards and promoting networks and linkages for regional laboratory services sharing.  Specifically, the meeting will: 1. Discuss and agree on a #Framework for national laboratory strategic plans; 2. Advocate for and obtain country buy-in to implement laboratory mapping in: 2.1. First high level laboratories (public health, reference and regional laboratories) within the Regional Collaborating Centre (#RCC) as part of the larger Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring and Surveillance Network (#AMRSNET) and Regional Integrated Surveillance and Laboratory Network (#RISLNET) agenda; and 2.2. Subsequently across entire national laboratory network to support laboratory system strengthening activities. 3. Identify and discuss ways to strengthen existing national and regional laboratory networks and ensure that are connected to their respective regional networks.  The meeting is held in #Lusaka, #Zambia from 02 to 04 May 2018 and will convene representatives from the Ministries of Health from the ten regional African Union Member States, namely; Republic of Angola, Republic of Botswana, Republic of Malawi, Republic of Mozambique, Kingdom of Lesotho, Republic of Namibia, Republic of South Africa, Kingdom of Swaziland, Republic of Zambia and Republic of Zimbabwe. #LabAfricaCDC2018 #Southern_AfricaCDC_RCC

Communiqué sur la "Formation sur la Communication des risques en Santé Publique pour les Chargés de la communication des Instituts Nationaux de Santé Publique en Afrique" tenue par Africa CDC en collaboration avec Observatoire National des Maladies Nouvelles et Emergentes, Tunisie, du 03 au 07 avril 2018.  Addis Abéba, le 10 avril 2018 - Formation sur la Communication des risques et des crises dans les situations d'urgence en Santé Publique pour les agents travaillant dans les Instituts Nationaux de Santé Publique (INSP) dans les États membres de l'Union africaine, organisée par les Centres Africains de Contrôle et de Prévention des Maladies (CACPM) en partenariat avec l'Observatoire National des Maladies Nouvelles et Emergentes (ONMNE) du Ministère de la Santé de Tunisie, tenue à Tunis, en Tunisie, du 03 au 07 avril 2018, dans la Salle de conférence Diamant de l’Hôtel Golden Tulip El Mechtel. La Communication des risques est au cœur des interventions de Santé Publique en cas d'épidémies et d'urgence sanitaire. Il s'agit de l'échange en temps réel d'informations, de conseils et d'opinions entre les experts, les fonctionnaires et les personnes qui font face à une menace pour leur bien-être, afin de leur permettre de prendre des décisions éclairées et d'adopter des comportements protecteurs. Elle va au-delà du concept traditionnel qui consiste principalement en un outil de diffusion de l'information au public sur les risques et les événements pour la santé, comme les éclosions de maladies et les instructions sur la façon de modifier les comportements afin d'atténuer ces risques. Dans le cadre des activités des CACPM visant à atteindre leurs objectifs stratégiques de renforcement des Institutions Nationales de Santé Publique et d'amélioration de la préparation et de l'intervention en cas d'urgence dans les États membres de l'Union africaine, les CACPM, conjointement avec le Ministère Tunisien de la Santé représenté par l'ONMNE, a organisé une formation de cinq jours sur la Communication des risques à l'intention des responsables de la communication de certains instituts nationaux de santé publique en Afrique. Cette formation comprenait des sessions didactiques suivies de jeux de rôle et d'exercices de santé publique. Le travail de cette formation était basé sur la communication scientifique, les études de cas, la formation sur les médias et la stratégie de communication à déployer comme mesure préventive mais aussi dans la gestion des crises en cas d'épidémies. Les connaissances conceptuelles des participants et leurs pratiques opérationnelles ont été renforcées pour faire face aux risques en santé publique. Ils devaient également mieux assurer l'interaction nécessaire avec les différents canaux de communication et de mobilisation préventive, ainsi qu'avec les médias et les réseaux sociaux. En post-formation, le projet des CACPM vise à établir une base de données et un lien entre les facilitateurs et les responsables de la communication afin de permettre un mentorat continu et un soutien technique en cas de besoin. L'objectif général de cette formation était de former les responsables de la communication sur la communication des risques dans les situations d'urgence de santé publique, par le renforcement des capacités essentielles de communication des risques dans le cadre des exigences de surveillance et d'intervention du Règlement Sanitaire International (RSI). Plus précisément, il s'agissait de comprendre la définition de la communication des risques pour les urgences de santé publique, de décrire le rôle de la communication efficace des risques dans les interventions d'urgence en santé publique, de définir les concepts de base de la planification de la communication des risques, les critères d'évaluation et le suivi des progrès de la communication des risques et de trouver des moyens d'établir des relations avec les principaux intervenants et partenaires. En outre, les responsables de la communication ont été formés aux compétences nécessaires à l'élaboration d'un plan d'action pratique pour la communication des risques en cas d'urgence de santé publique. Notons que la cérémonie d'ouverture de cette formation a été conduite par S.E. Mr Imed Hammami, Ministre de la Santé de la République Tunisienne en présence du Représentant Pays de l'OMS et des hauts cadres du Ministère de la Santé. La cérémonie de clôture a été conduite par Mr Khaldi Mohamed Tayeb, Officier de liaison de l'Union Africaine en Libye basé à Tunis.   Plus d'informations, visitez: www.africacdc.org  Contact : Dr Chrys Promesse KANIKI K. | Communications Officer | Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention | African Union Commission | KanikiC@africa-union.org | Tel: +251 909 537 791  A propos des CACPM Les CACPM aident  tous les pays africains à améliorer la surveillance, les interventions d'urgence et la prévention des maladies infectieuses. Il s'agit notamment de faire face aux épidémies, aux catastrophes naturelles et d'origine humaine, ainsi qu'aux événements de santé publique d'intérêt régional et international. Ils visent en outre à renforcer la capacité de réduire la charge de morbidité sur le continent.  tinyurl.com/y9kt4t8x

Déclaration de l'African Union à l'occasion de la #Journée_mondiale contre le #paludisme:  Dix-huit ans après la Déclaration historique d'Abuja sur l'initiative #Roll_Back_Malaria (Faire reculer le paludisme), signée par les Chefs d'État et de gGuvernement le 25 avril 2000, les pays africains continuent d'être les plus touchés par l'épidémie de paludisme, avec 90 % de la charge de la maladie sur le continent.  Reconnaissant que le paludisme est une menace énorme pour la santé publique, les dirigeants africains ont déclaré le #25avril #Journée_du_paludisme afin de s'assurer que la maladie reste en tête de l'agenda politique et des programmes du continent. Aujourd'hui, alors que nous nous joignons à la communauté des nations pour commémorer la #Journée_mondiale_du_paludisme sous le thème " #Prêt_à_vaincre_le_paludisme ", nous sommes conscients du fait que l'éradication du paludisme est une responsabilité collective qui exige que chaque individu dans nos communautés prenne des mesures concertées et, plus largement, nous avons besoin de partenariats durables.   Sans une action renouvelée et urgente, les principaux progrès réalisés dans la lutte contre le paludisme risquent d'être réduits à néant. L'Union africaine appelle à investir davantage et à élargir la couverture des outils éprouvés qui permettent de #prévenir, de #diagnostiquer et de #traiter le paludisme. Bien qu'il y ait eu des progrès remarquables dans la lutte contre le paludisme au fil des ans, le rapport mondial sur le paludisme de 2017 souligne que les progrès ont stagné à l'échelle mondiale.  Le rythme actuel est insuffisant pour atteindre l'objectif ambitieux et audacieux de réduire les taux de mortalité due au paludisme à zéro dans tous les pays à au moins 40 % d'ici à 2020, comme le prévoit le Cadre catalytique pour mettre fin au sida, à la tuberculose et éliminer le paludisme en Afrique d'ici à 2030. Les États membres de l'Union africaine devraient donc accélérer les efforts vers l'accès universel à la #prévention, au #diagnostic et au #traitement du paludisme, transformer la surveillance du paludisme en une intervention de base, exploiter l'innovation et développer la recherche, renforcer l'environnement favorable et accélérer les efforts vers l'élimination et l'absence de paludisme.  Nous ne pourrons pas réaliser les aspirations ambitieuses de développement socio-économique, de croissance économique inclusive et le programme de transformation structurelle de l'Afrique d'ici 2063 si nous n'abordons pas le programme de santé avec audace. Alors que nous avons de nombreuses priorités concurrentes en matière de développement sur le continent, l'énorme boom économique des pays africains offre la possibilité d'améliorer la prestation de services dans les domaines de la santé, de l'éducation, de l'électricité, de l'eau, de l'assainissement et de la promotion de l'hygiène.  Les pays africains doivent renouveler leur engagement et renforcer les instruments pour parvenir à une #Afrique_sans_paludisme_d_ici2030, conformément au Cadre catalytique pour mettre fin au sida, à la tuberculose et éliminer le paludisme en Afrique d'ici 2030, adopté par les chefs d'État et de gouvernement lors du Sommet de juillet 2016.  On estime que le paludisme à lui seul prive le continent de 12 milliards de dollars par an en pertes de productivité, en investissements et en coûts associés aux soins de santé. Il est donc essentiel que nous maintenions l'engagement politique, tel qu'énoncé dans notre Agenda 2063 continental, d'éliminer le paludisme en Afrique d'ici 2030 grâce à un financement intérieur accru, à un meilleur accès à des interventions vitales contre le paludisme, ainsi qu'à des systèmes de santé plus robustes. Le paludisme, maladie traitable et évitable, coûte déjà à l'économie du continent africain 12 milliards de dollars par an en pertes directes et 1,3 % de la croissance annuelle perdue du PIB.  En juillet prochain, les chefs d'État et de gouvernement de l'Union africaine et le Partenariat Faire reculer le paludisme lanceront conjointement la campagne "Zero Malaria Starts with Me", une campagne publique à l'échelle du continent pour une Afrique sans paludisme. Dans le cadre de la campagne panafricaine "Zero Malaria Starts with Me", les dirigeants seront invités à s'engager publiquement à soutenir et à prendre des engagements concrets en faveur de l'élimination du paludisme. Cette campagne plaidera en faveur d'une augmentation du financement extérieur et intérieur pour l'élimination du paludisme, d'une sensibilisation et d'une appropriation au niveau communautaire et d'un soutien essentiel à la mission des pays où le paludisme est endémique.  Africa CDC (#CACPM), créé en 2017, a bénéficié d'un soutien accru à tous les pays africains pour améliorer la surveillance, les interventions d'urgence et la prévention des maladies infectieuses. Il s'agit notamment de faire face aux épidémies, aux catastrophes naturelles et d'origine humaine, ainsi qu'aux événements de santé publique d'intérêt régional et international. Ce nouvel ordre de santé publique en Afrique améliorera notre réponse au paludisme.   Son Excellence Mme Amira El Fadil Commissaire aux affaires sociales Commission de l'Union africaine https://tinyurl.com/y9rso9ke

African Union Statement on the Occasion of the #World_Malaria_Day:  Eighteen years after the historic Abuja Declaration on #Roll_Back_Malaria was signed by Heads of State and Government on 25 April 2000, African countries continue to bear the heaviest brunt of the Malaria epidemic with 90% of the disease burden on the continent.  Recognising that Malaria is a huge public health threat African leaders declared #25April as #Malaria_Day to ensure that the disease remains high at the policy and political agenda of the continent. Today as we join the community of nations to commemorate the World Malaria Day under the theme "#Ready_to_Beat_Malaria" we are cognizant of the fact that ending Malaria is a collective responsibility that requires every individual in our communities to take concerted action and more broadly we need sustained partnerships.  Without renewed and urgent action, the major gains in the fight against malaria are under threat of being reversed. The African Union calls for greater investment and expanded coverage of proven tools that prevent, diagnose and treat malaria. While there has been remarkable progress in responding to Malaria over the years the 2017 World malaria report highlights that progress has stalled globally.   The current pace is insufficient to achieve the bold and ambitious target to reduce malaria mortality rates to zero in all countries to at least 40% by 2020 as laid out in the Catalytic Framework to end AIDS, TB and Eliminate Malaria in Africa by 2030. African Union Member States should thus accelerate efforts towards universal access to #malaria_prevention, #diagnosis and #treatment, transform malaria surveillance into a core intervention, harness innovation and expand research, strengthen the enabling environment and accelerate efforts towards elimination and malaria free status.  We cannot achieve the ambitious aspirations for socio-economic development, inclusive economic growth and Africa’s structural transformation Agenda by 2063 if we do not address the health agenda boldly. While we have many competing development priorities on the continent, African countries’ huge economic boom provides an opportunity for improved service delivery in the areas of health as well as education, power, water, sanitation and hygiene promotion.  African nations must renew their commitment and strengthen instruments to attain a #malaria_free_Africa_by2030 in line with the Catalytic Framework to end AIDS, TB and Eliminate Malaria in Africa by 2030 adopted by Heads of State and Government in at the July 2016 Summit.  Malaria alone is estimated to rob the continent of US$12 billion per year in lost productivity, investment and associated health care costs. It is therefore critical that we sustain the political commitment, as articulated in our continental Agenda 2063, to eliminate malaria in Africa by 2030 through increased domestic financing, increased access to life-saving malaria interventions, as well as more robust health systems. Malaria, a treatable and preventable disease, already costs the African continent’s economy US$ 12 billion per year in direct losses, and 1.3% of lost annual GDP growth.,  This July the African Union Heads of State and Government and the Roll Back Malaria Partnership will jointly launch the “Zero Malaria Starts with Me” a continent-wide public-facing campaign for a malaria-free Africa. The campaign will provide high-level engagement with government, private sector and civil society leaders: as part of the pan-African “Zero Malaria Starts with Me” campaign, leaders will be invited to publicly pledge their support to and make concrete commitments towards malaria elimination. It will advocate for an increase in external and domestic funding for malaria elimination, increase awareness and ownership at the community level and provide mission-critical support to malaria endemic countries.  The Africa CDC established in 2017 has seen increased support to all African countries to improve surveillance, emergency response, and prevention of infectious diseases. This includes addressing outbreaks, man-made and natural disasters, and public health events of regional and international concern. This new public health order in Africa will improve our response to malaria.   Her Excellency Mrs. Amira El Fadil Commissioner for Social Affairs African Union Commission https://tinyurl.com/y9rso9ke

Africa CDC conducted a training on Regional Public Health #Information_Sharing Platform using #ECHO_platform for Surveillance Activities, in Eastern Africa RCC, from 21 to 23 March 2018, in Nairobi, Kenya.  This training provided African Union MS with a platform to timely share public health information in terms of Public health threats/ epidemiological trends and shared best practices in addressing public health priorities within the region for strengthening individual countries preparedness and response capacities for regional benefits.  It also provided an educational platform between MS and experts on identified regional public health priorities and identified gaps in IHR core competencies. #EastEchoTraining #AfricaCDCEcho2018 #ProjectECHO World Health Organization African Region.  Three trainings (immersion training and 2 regional trainings) have been conducted on the Regional Public Health Information Sharing Platform: Southern and Central Africa region are currently implementing the platform.  Africa CDC Regional Public Health Information Sharing Platform for its RCCs is built on #ProjectECHO_ICTs, low cost and works in settings with limited bandwidth to share documents, record and archive discussions. It also has an enhanced cloud-based solution, called Zoom, designed to connect mobile, desktop and room systems and is optimized for connecting to low bandwidth, rural areas.  Africa CDC key steps in establishing and implementing its Regional Public Health Information Sharing Platform are:  1. Equip RCCs with resources needed to establish coordinating points for connections with regional MS and Africa CDC Secretariat. 2. Communication sharing across borders for AU Member States to start engage in timely public health information sharing 4 action. 3. Review MS #JEE_reports to identify gaps & #IHR technical attention areas and ensure countries can prevent, detect and rapidly respond to public health risks 4. Informed by evaluation the platform could be expanded from national level to local level for rapid disease detection and response.  #EastEchoTraining #AfricaCDCEcho2018.  Communication Team: Promesse Chrys Kaniki, Headquarters Africa CDC, Addis Ababa Thomas Joly Ngbonga, Headquarters Africa CDC, Addis Ababa Adukonjo Mhiraf Asheber, Eastern Africa RCC, Nairobi Dot Njagi, Southern Africa RCC, Lusaka

About #Risk_Communication in Public Health training in Tunisia first week of April...  25 pays africains débattent à Tunis de la communication en levier essentiel face aux risques santé publique.  La Tunisie a appelé à renforcer la coopération interafricaine en matière de prévention et de gestion des risques santé, à travers la consolidation des capacités nécessaires, les échanges d’expériences et la coordination des efforts. Ouvrant les travaux du séminaire africain sur la communication des risques dans le domaine de la santé publique, qui a démarré mardi à Tunis, avec la participation des représentants de 25 pays de toutes les sous-régions du continent, le ministre de la Santé, Imed Hammami a souligné que cette coopération devenue impérative, bénéficiant de l’appui des organismes internationaux. Elle ne peut être efficace que si les et les méthodes de de prévention et de lutte sont les mieux adaptées et harmonisées et s’appuient efficacement sur une communication appropriée. A cet effet, il a mis en exergue l’importance de l’anticipation des risques et épidémies, de la planification des actions à entreprendre dans le cadre d’une stratégie préétablie et sur la base de procédures fixées.  Le ministre de la Santé a réaffirmé à cette occasion, l’engagement de la Tunisie à assumer pleinement son rôle dans le cadre du règlement sanitaire international et de mettre en partage ses potentialités et son expertise en la matière. Organisé, à l’initiative de la Commission de l’Union africaine, par le Centre africain de prévention et de lutte contre les maladies (CDC africain) conjointement avec l’Observatoire national de des maladies nouvelles et émergentes (ONMNE), ce séminaire se poursuivra jusqu’au samedi 7 avril 2018. Les travaux s’articulent autour de communications scientifiques, d’études de cas, de média-training et de stratégie de communication à déployer à titre préventif mais aussi en gestion de crise en cas d’épidémie. Les participants auront à renforcer à cette occasion, leurs connaissances conceptuelles et leurs pratiques opérationnelles face aux risques santé publique. Ils auront également à mieux assurer l’interaction nécessaire avec les différents canaux de communication et de mobilisation préventive, ainsi que les médias et les réseaux sociaux. « La richesse de son expérience acquise et la qualification de ses institutions et de ses compétences ont érigé la Tunisie en acteur de référence en matière de prévention et de gestion des risques santé publique et de communication appropriée, a déclaré le Pr Nissaf Ben Alaya, directrice générale de l’ONMNE. A ce titre, a-t-elle ajouté, le ministère de la Santé, conscient de l’impératif de coopération et de la coordination, est en interaction continue avec les pays frères et amis et les institutions régionales et internationales. »   https://tinyurl.com/ybdnqcyd

#Throwback Back to images... Discover the participants in the Africa CDC Risk Communication Training organized from 03 to 07 April 2018 in Tunisia...  13. Anueyiagu Emmanuel Chimezie is a Risk Communications Officer with the #Nigeria Centre for Disease Control. In his role, he is responsible for the development of risk communications strategies, messages including graphics, disease specific advisory notes, communications campaigns and related activities.  He played a key role during the 2016/2017 Meningitis outbreak in Nigeria, planning and supervising risk communications activities in the most affected States of Zamfara, Sokoto and Katsina. He has also been part of the incident management system for Yellow fever, Lassa fever, Monkeypox and Cholera as a member of the risk communications pillar.  His expertise cuts across graphics development, social media utilisation, community engagement and mobilisation amongst others.  Currently, Chimezie is co-leading the communications campaign for Nigeria's Lassa fever outbreak which is the largest outbreak of the disease. #PHRiskCom2018

Africa's unsung scientists finally get their own journal to spread research.  A #new_journal to showcase Africa’s often-overlooked scientific research has been launched to give the continent’s scientists better global recognition. Scientific African will be the first “mega-journal” in Africa. It was unveiled in Kigali last week at Africa’s biggest science conference, the #Next_Einstein_Forum (NEF) conference, and the first issue is scheduled to be published at the end of the summer.  Its editor, Dr Benjamin Gyampoh, said the journal would address the problem of African scientists going unrecognised for pioneering work because they lacked access to quality publications.   “There are many reputable journals but there is a low number of Africans publishing in them partly because the costs are so high,” Gyampoh said. “We are reducing these costs while providing a platform for world-class research, across different disciplines and on par with any published around the world.”  Publication in Scientific African will cost $200, around half of what it costs in most recognised journals. The journal was founded by the #NEF, an initiative of the African Institute of Mathematical Sciences (Aims), and is backed by global publishing site Elsevier.  https://tinyurl.com/yb6c364p

High Level Africa CDC and SADC Meeting: #Day2 After the #Bilateral meeting on 16th April, the meeting continued today with participants from #SADC Member States. The Commissioner for Social Affairs H.E. Amira Elfadil Mohamed @Elfadil_DSA delivered the Opening Remarks and reminded delegates of the #importance of #collaboration between African Union Member States, #AfricaCDC and #SADC.  In turn, taking the floor, "#SADC_Secretariat Mr #JosephMthetwa said: "We need to focus on Diseases affecting SADC Region and not forgetting #NCDs".   Then, The Acting Director of Africa CDC, Dr #Benjamin_Djoudalbaye, gave an Overview on Africa CDC. He tackled about the 5 pillars, the Operations Model , the Strategic Plan - One Year Update - the Role of Africa CDC, RCCs and Member States  and Networks (#AMRSNET, #RILSNET).  After Dr Benjamin @djoudalbaye presentation, Delegates expressed their satisfaction about the Progress made thus far by Africa CDC; main challenge would be building capacity, harnessing and integrating the resources.  Great strides have been done to establish AfricaCDC however the plea is to advocate and raise awareness for the SouthernRCC within the region. Its success will be dependent on the involvement of the MS such as secondment of staff to the RCC; said Dr #Victor_Mukonka.  The specific objectives of the meeting included: - Identify priority areas of focus for public health interventions for the region; - Identify key areas of collaboration (short-term and long-term) between Africa CDC and SADC Secretariat; - Implementation strategies of RISLNET in SADC region.   General Discussions brought out the following: (a) #Priority_areas for the Southern RCC #agreed by MS: - Capacity building,  - Mapping of assets,  - Multi-sectorial collaboration,  - AMR and sustainability and  - Use of available resources within Africa.   (b) #Areas of collaboration #AfricaCDC_SADC: - Cholera (regional strategy and research), - Malaria,  - AntiMicrobial Resistance with a focus on MDR,  - Pandemic preparedness and response.  #AfricaCDC_SADC #AddisAbaba 16-18April2018

Africa CDC is organizing a High Level Meeting with Permanent Secretaries / Secretaries of Health / Principal Secretaries / Director Generals of the SADC Region.  This meeting is currently being held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia from today 16th to 18th April 2018 at the Headquarters of the African Union Commission.  The main objectives of the meeting include: • Share background information on #AfricaCDC and #SADC Secretariats including the mandates and operation structures of both organisations; • Identify key areas of collaboration between Africa CDC and SADC Secretariats; • Identify priority areas of focus for Public Health interventions for the region; • Implementation strategies of #RISLNET in #SADC_Region.  For this first day, a #Bilateral_meeting between SADC and Africa CDC is organized and general discussions will focus on:  - Public Health Priority Activities in the Region  - Areas of Collaboration  - Support for SADC Secretariat.

Key steps in establishing and implementing Africa CDC Regional Public Health Information Sharing Platforms  - Equip Africa CDC Regional Collaborating Centres (RCCs) with resources needed for establishment of information sharing platform. RCCs will serve as he hub for coordinating with regional Member States and Africa CDC Secretariat.   -Information Sharing: start communication across borders and engage Member States in the platform. This will enable Member States in each region to engage in timely public health information sharing for action.  -Post Joint External Evaluation Planning and Educational Platform. The platform will be used to aid in review of country’s JEE reports to identify gaps and IHR technical areas in need of attention and ensure that countries are able to prevent, detect and rapidly respond to public health risks   -IHR indicators will  be selected to guide the discussion, best experience sharing and identification of subject matter experts for capacity building. The platform will be used by countries to empower each other by sharing their experiences and assessments. Countries can identify best practices and identify areas of collaboration within the region.  -Platform expansion:  basing on performance evaluation and input from data sharing taskforce established during the RCC meetings the platform will be expanded from national level to local level for rapid disease detection and response.  In pictures: participants of the East Africa Regional Collaborating Centre Training on the Africa CDC on the Regional Public Health Information Sharing Platform this week. Regional Public Health Information Sharing Platform forAfrica CDC and its RCCs is built on @ProjectECHO ICTs that are low cost and work in settings with limited bandwith to share documents, record and archive  discussions.

Three trainings: immersion training and 2 regional trainings have been conducted on the Regional Public Health Information Sharing Platform. Southern and Central Africa region are currently implementing the platform. The Platform is providing opportunities for timely sharing of information, best practices and  educational platform in addressing regional public health  priorities and for coordinated response/actions within regions.

The Africa CDC and its East Africa Regional Collaborating Centre provided training today in Kenya on its Regional Public Health Information Sharing Platform.Critical, life-saving information and data sharing across MS is of the top priority activities that need to be in place to further move Africa CDC strategic actions: - Adhering to Heads of State and Government  Declaration on IHR implementation where they are mindful of the efforts being made by Africa CDC in disease surveillance, detection and response including emergency preparedness, as well as its important role in further strengthening the International Health Regulations (IHR) in the continent  - Strengthening MS in early detection  and rapid response to public health events taking advantage of experience sharing and coordinated preparedness and response across borders - Implementing Africa CDC strategic pillar on Information Systems that aims at developing and strengthen information systems that support public health strategies  - Implementing RCC meeting decision on the need for Africa CDC to establish a mechanism for sharing information on public health events as they occur for timely regional preparedness and response  - Implementing IHR to achieve International public health security  by  taking advantage of developments in biotechnology, surveillance systems, and - Information technology that if properly used can facilitate timely detection, rapid data/information sharing and timely response.   👇🏻Participants in selected pictures.

@AfricaCDC  Director @JNkengasong officially opens the First International Conference on (Re) Emegerging Infectious Diseases yesterday in Addis Ababa. #ICREAD2018 will:   - Discuss ways to strengthen disease intelligence using accurate data and predictions -Discuss threats that emerging infectious diseases pose to global health seucity -Attract, showcase and maintain new, early career, and underrepresented investigators to this rapidly changing field of research and translate novel findings into clinical practice -Summarise current research findings and assess their contribution in detecting, treating, managing and containing (re) emerging infectious diseases -Translate new data to treatment intervention guidelines while creating awareness on the social, economic and political impact of (re-emerging) infectious diseases.

Organized by the Africa Centres for Diseases Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and Virology Education, the International Conference on (Re-) Emerging Infectious Diseases (ICREID) from  , ICREID is a global platform that brings together experts from around the world involved in emerging diseases in an interactive conference setting. In line with the Global Health Security Agenda (GHSA) and International Health Regulations (IHR), this meeting serves as a catalyst to safeguard global health security by responding and preventing acute public health threats and improving patient outcomes.   ICREID is a highly scientific and educational abstract- driven conference consisting of key note speeches, state-of-the-art lectures, oral and poster abstract presentations, roundtable discussions, debates and in-depth discussions to exchange knowledge on the latest developments on ongoing challenges to prevent, respond, control and management outbreaks of various emerging and re-emerging diseases.   The pressing need for a scientific platform is demonstrated by both the high number of participants attending the meeting as well as the number of abstracts  received. Out of the submitted abstracts, 12 were accepted for oral abstract presentations and 42 for poster presentations. In addition to the presentations on real life experiences, a large number of well-recognised experts have confirmed the need for informational exchange and education by giving didactic lectures covering several important topics in preventing and managing an outbreak.   Several international networks support the ICREID mission by actively participating in the meeting. The conference will provide a platform where new data will be translated to treatment and intervention guidelines and will create a unique opportunity for community building and networking. Selected photos taken on the first day of the conference 12.03.2018

The 2017 Africa CDC Annual Report highlights that considerable progress has been made in establishing the Africa CDC since it was launched in January 2017 by Africa’s Heads of State and Government. Africa CDC has primarily focused its operational activities on five strategic pillars: 1) surveillance and disease intelligence, 2) emergency preparedness and response (with a focus on pandemics), 3) laboratory systems and networks, 4) innovative information systems, and 5) public health institutes and research. From an administrative perspective, the Africa CDC governance structure and a corresponding policy manual have been developed and approved by the Africa CDC Governing Board. Recruitment of the first cohort of permanent staff is ongoing. Moreover, despite being in its infancy, Africa CDC effectively supported nine outbreak responses in several Member States during 2017. The report further highlights the priorities for 2018: 1) strengthened National Public Health Institutes and five Africa CDC Regional Collaborating Centres, 2) Regional Integrated Surveillance and Laboratory Network established, 3) a broad public health workforce agenda in the areas of the field epidemiology, laboratory leadership, and public health informatics established and 5) launch a public-private philanthropic partnership and foster partnerships at various levels  with business, technical partners and donors to effectively respond to public health threats.

Dr. John Nkengasong, director of Africa CDC, joined the International Association of National Public Health Institutes at its annual meeting in Rome, Italy.   IANPHI and Africa CDC are working together to build capacity in African NPHIs, as well as create supportive partnerships across networks.  #IANPHIMtg2017 #publichealth #globalhealth

The Africa CDC has launched new networks that will help the continent fight health threats through scientific evidence as the basis for policy implementation and resource allocation.
